results.title: The Funniest man in the world
results.creator_credit: Vernon P. Becker and Mel May
results.brief_description: A nostalgic look at the life and times of Charlie Chaplin, still considered to be one of the funniest and best slapstick actors in motion picture history. Born in London on 16 April 1889, to parents of music hall fame who were later to divorce, Charlie lived a fairly harsh existence with his mother and older brother Sidney. However Charlie, attracted to the world of stage, finds himself by his early teens winning parts in the stage plays “Jim, a romance of cockney” and “Sherlock Holmes”. It is not long before Chaplin ends up in the United States joining Mack Sennet’s Keystone Films, and the rest, as they say, is history. Narrated by Douglas Fairbanks, Jr this documentary follows Chaplin’s career featuring excerpts from many of his films, including “A Night out”, “The Tramp”, “The Immigrant”, Easy Street” among others and starring such actors as Roscoe “Fatty Arbuckle, Marie Dressler, Douglas Fairbanks, Oliver Hardy, Mary Pickford, Mack Swain and Ben Turpin. The film also includes additional unused new scenes and rare archival newsreel footage of Chaplin in Hollywood with Stan Laurel, Chaplin at 16 and in a UK Music Hall. The “Little Tramp” lives on.

constellations_other.name: Processing grief through art
constellations_other.description: Thor: Love and Thunder begins with Thor meditating in a robe designed by Gumbaynggirr/Bundjalung artist Otis Hope Carey, best known for Ngalunggirr miinggi (healing spirit) (2020), a painting that expresses his grief over the loss of grandmother. Many artists process grief through their creative work.

results.title: The Funeral
results.creator_credit: Mary Kane, October Films and Abel Ferrara
results.brief_description: Working from an original screenplay from his long time collaborator Nicholas St John, Abel Ferrara’s “The Funeral” sees the maverick director working in a more low key mode. That’s not to say of course that “The Funeral” doesn’t have Ferrara’s usual trademarks; seething violence, spiritual males and cathartic redemption. The film’s melancholic study of a crime family in crisis is set off by the murder of 22 year old Johnny Tempio (Vincent Gallo), shot dead in a movie theatre by a rival gang. His grief stricken brothers (Christopher Walken and Chris Penn) vow bloody revenge, while the women (Annabella Sciorra and Isabella Rossellini) of the family look for a more peaceful resolution. Ferrara is a master of transcending conventional genres as he proved with his bold reinvention of the vampire movie in The Addiction (1995) and his rabid cop drama Bad Lieutenant (1992). Again Ferrara manages to transcend the cliches of the gangster film as the bloody quest for revenge becomes an internal affair, leaving the mafia brothers to contemplate the nature of guilt and the futility of retribution. 1996 Venice Film Festival winner for Best Supporting Actor (Chris Penn) and the OCIC (Organisation Catholique Internationale du Cinema) Award for Abel Ferrara. Cast includes: Benicio del Toro, Gretchen Mol.

results.title: The Funeral
results.creator_credit: Yasushi Tamaoki, Yutaka Okada and Juzo Itami
results.brief_description: The Funeral is a story about three days in which a married couple, an actor and an actress, must preside over a traditional, Japanese funeral for a member of the family. Their confusion, the complex demands this situation presents and the reactions of other participants create a story that is simultaneously comic, sad and moving.

results.title: The Fundamentals of tennis
results.brief_description: Donald Budge demonstrates forehand, backhand, service, volley and half-volley; the strokes are analysed and helpful suggestions for their proper execution are made. The film was sponsored by the USA Lawn Tennis Association.

results.title: The Fundamentals of film making. No.1: learning the language
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Fundamentals of film making”.
An introduction to moving picture photography using the written word in an analogy with the completed film: how a succession of single frames, equivalent of a letter in a single word, gives an impression of continuous movement; the definition and examples of a “shot” likening it to a word in a sentence; then the “sequence” equivalent of a paragraph or chapter, depending on length. The purpose terms used and results achieved when camera angles are varied and the camera moved, and the effect of varying the time scale. How to make basic transitions (cut, fade, mix) from shot to shot.

group_siblings.title: The Fundamentals of film making - No.2: using the camera

results.title: The Fundamentals of film making - No.2: using the camera
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Fundamentals of film making”.
An introduction to moving picture camera use; loading, running off leader and how to avoid fogging; how to keep the camera steady and use of a tripod; panning and common faults to avoid; the use of the zoom and the need for restraint; placing of the camera and avoidance of the jump cut; pitfalls of reverse action and parallax.

results.title: The Fun gap
results.creator_credit: Derek Wright, New Zealand National Film Unit and John King
results.brief_description: A comprehensive look at the types of sporting activities being provided to the intellectually and physically handicapped of all ages. Special education staff and the participants themselves, including two hearing-impaired people, a young paraplegic, a blind yachtsman and some aged persons, comment on the benefits they perceive in taking part.

results.title: The Fully ordained meat pie
results.creator_credit: Janet Bell, Gillian Coote and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This documentary looks at the attitude of the Church towards the ordination of women as priests, and follows a group of women lobbying for the right to be ordained into the Anglican priesthood. Featured in the program are Dr. Patricia Brennan, the Reverend Alison Cheek and Sister Angela of Stroud.

results.title: The Full Monty
results.creator_credit: Uberto Pasolini, Redwave Productions and Peter Cattaneo
results.brief_description:
Robert Carlyle stars as Gaz in this irreverent comedy set in the middle-England working class town of Sheffield. He is a jobless steel worker who dreams up an outrageous scheme to pull himself and his mates out of the personal and financial doldrums of long term unemployment. After seeing the money and adulation lauded upon the male exotic dance team The Chippendales by the females of the town, he rounds up willing and reticent participants for a review to be named the Full Monty. They are a collection of pigeon-chested, pot-bellied, heavy drinking, pale, wrinkly middle-aged strippers with one solitary gimmick - it all comes off!
Cast also includes: Tom Wilkinson, Mark Addy
